open_questions.title: Computer architecture
open_questions.description: What is computer architecture?
open_questions.prompt: You are evaluating a junior-level candidate. Answer the question: "What is computer architecture?" Requirements: - Define the concept in your own words - Give a small example - Mention a common pitfall or best practice Style: - Clear, structured, concise. - Use code snippets only if they add clarity. - Avoid vague statements.
open_questions.aiEvaluationHint: Expect the answer to address: Define the concept in your own words; Give a small example; Mention a common pitfall or best practice. Penalize answers that miss key requirements.

referenceAnswers.text: Computer architecture refers to the design and organization of the core components of a computer system, including the central processing unit (CPU), memory, and the system's interconnections. It encompasses the rules and methods that describe the functionality, organization, and implementation of computer systems. Key aspects include processor design, memory management, data representation, and instruction set architecture. It determines how hardware and software interact to deliver the functional requirements of a computer, influencing aspects like processing speed, power consumption, and cost.
keyPoints: Define the concept in your own words
Give a small example
Mention a common pitfall or best practice

open_questions.title: The three categories of computer architecture
open_questions.description: What are the three categories of computer architecture?
open_questions.prompt: You are evaluating a junior-level candidate. Answer the question: "What are the three categories of computer architecture?" Requirements: - Define the concept in your own words - Give a small example - Mention a common pitfall or best practice Style: - Clear, structured, concise. - Use code snippets only if they add clarity. - Avoid vague statements.
open_questions.aiEvaluationHint: Expect the answer to address: Define the concept in your own words; Give a small example; Mention a common pitfall or best practice. Penalize answers that miss key requirements.

referenceAnswers.text: System Design: This includes the hardware components within a system, such as data processors, memory controllers, and direct memory access. Instruction Set Architecture (ISA): This defines the machine code that a processor can execute, as well as the native commands and functions of the processor. Microarchitecture: This deals with the design of the processor's internal architecture, including data paths, pipelines, and control logic, influencing how it implements the ISA.
keyPoints: Define the concept in your own words
Give a small example
Mention a common pitfall or best practice

open_questions.title: The Von Neumann architecture, and how
open_questions.description: What is the Von Neumann architecture, and how does it differ from Harvard architecture?
open_questions.prompt: You are evaluating a junior-level candidate. Answer the question: "What is the Von Neumann architecture, and how does it differ from Harvard architecture?" Requirements: - Define the concept in your own words - Give a small example - Mention a common pitfall or best practice Style: - Clear, structured, concise. - Use code snippets only if they add clarity. - Avoid vague statements.
open_questions.aiEvaluationHint: Expect the answer to address: Define the concept in your own words; Give a small example; Mention a common pitfall or best practice. Penalize answers that miss key requirements.

referenceAnswers.text: The Von Neumann architecture is a computer architecture that stores program instructions and data in a single memory unit. It uses a single bus for both instruction and data fetching. In contrast, Harvard architecture separates instruction and data memory, typically using separate buses. This separation allows for simultaneous instruction fetch and data access, potentially improving performance.
keyPoints: Define the concept in your own words
Give a small example
Mention a common pitfall or best practice

open_questions.title: Some of the components of a
open_questions.description: What are some of the components of a microprocessor?
open_questions.prompt: You are evaluating a junior-level candidate. Answer the question: "What are some of the components of a microprocessor?" Requirements: - Define the concept in your own words - Give a small example - Mention a common pitfall or best practice Style: - Clear, structured, concise. - Use code snippets only if they add clarity. - Avoid vague statements.
open_questions.aiEvaluationHint: Expect the answer to address: Define the concept in your own words; Give a small example; Mention a common pitfall or best practice. Penalize answers that miss key requirements.

referenceAnswers.text: Arithmetic Logic Unit (ALU): Performs arithmetic and logical operations. Control Unit (CU): Directs the operation of the processor, managing and coordinating its components. Registers: Small, fast storage locations for temporary data or instructions. Cache Memory: A small-sized type of volatile computer memory that provides high-speed data access to a processor. Buses: Act as communication systems that transfer data between components inside or outside of a microprocessor. Clock: Controls the timing of all computer operations. Instruction Decoder: Interprets and converts instructions into signals for the ALU or other components.
keyPoints: Define the concept in your own words
Give a small example
Mention a common pitfall or best practice

open_questions.title: The main differences between a CPU
open_questions.description: Explain the main differences between a CPU and a GPU?
open_questions.prompt: You are evaluating a junior-level candidate. Answer the question: "Explain the main differences between a CPU and a GPU?" Requirements: - Define the concept in your own words - Give a small example - Mention a common pitfall or best practice Style: - Clear, structured, concise. - Use code snippets only if they add clarity. - Avoid vague statements.
open_questions.aiEvaluationHint: Expect the answer to address: Define the concept in your own words; Give a small example; Mention a common pitfall or best practice. Penalize answers that miss key requirements.

referenceAnswers.text: A CPU (Central Processing Unit) and a GPU (Graphics Processing Unit) are both types of processors, but they are designed for different tasks: CPU (Central Processing Unit): Generally optimized for sequential processing and tasks that require complex decision-making. Well-suited for tasks like general-purpose computing, system management, and executing single-threaded applications. Typically consists of fewer but more powerful cores. GPU (Graphics Processing Unit): Optimized for parallel processing and tasks that involve large amounts of data parallelism, such as rendering graphics, image processing, and machine learning. Excel in tasks that can be divided into many smaller tasks that can be processed simultaneously. Comprised of a larger number of less powerful cores compared to CPUs, allowing for highly parallel computation.
keyPoints: Define the concept in your own words
Give a small example
Mention a common pitfall or best practice

open_questions.title: The purpose of the CPU cache
open_questions.description: What is the purpose of the CPU cache in computer architecture.?
open_questions.prompt: You are evaluating a junior-level candidate. Answer the question: "What is the purpose of the CPU cache in computer architecture.?" Requirements: - Define the concept in your own words - Give a small example - Mention a common pitfall or best practice Style: - Clear, structured, concise. - Use code snippets only if they add clarity. - Avoid vague statements.
open_questions.aiEvaluationHint: Expect the answer to address: Define the concept in your own words; Give a small example; Mention a common pitfall or best practice. Penalize answers that miss key requirements.

referenceAnswers.text: The CPU cache is a small, high-speed memory unit located between the CPU and main memory. It stores frequently accessed data and instructions to reduce the time it takes to fetch them from slower main memory. The cache improves performance by reducing memory access latency and increasing the CPU's effective speed.
keyPoints: Define the concept in your own words
Give a small example
Mention a common pitfall or best practice

open_questions.title: A cache miss
open_questions.description: What is a cache miss?
open_questions.prompt: You are evaluating a junior-level candidate. Answer the question: "What is a cache miss?" Requirements: - Define the concept in your own words - Give a small example - Mention a common pitfall or best practice Style: - Clear, structured, concise. - Use code snippets only if they add clarity. - Avoid vague statements.
open_questions.aiEvaluationHint: Expect the answer to address: Define the concept in your own words; Give a small example; Mention a common pitfall or best practice. Penalize answers that miss key requirements.

referenceAnswers.text: A cache miss is an event in computer systems where the data requested by the CPU is not found in the cache memory. When this happens, the system must fetch the data from a slower tier of memory, typically the main RAM, leading to longer access times and reduced performance. Cache misses are significant in performance tuning and cache design considerations.
keyPoints: Define the concept in your own words
Give a small example
Mention a common pitfall or best practice

open_questions.title: The concept of cache coherence in
open_questions.description: Explain the concept of cache coherence in multiprocessor systems.?
open_questions.prompt: You are evaluating a junior-level candidate. Answer the question: "Explain the concept of cache coherence in multiprocessor systems.?" Requirements: - Define the concept in your own words - Give a small example - Mention a common pitfall or best practice Style: - Clear, structured, concise. - Use code snippets only if they add clarity. - Avoid vague statements.
open_questions.aiEvaluationHint: Expect the answer to address: Define the concept in your own words; Give a small example; Mention a common pitfall or best practice. Penalize answers that miss key requirements.

referenceAnswers.text: Cache coherence refers to the consistency of data stored in different caches in a multiprocessor system. Maintaining cache coherence is crucial to ensure that all processors see a consistent view of memory. Techniques like invalidation-based and update-based protocols (e.g., MESI) are used to achieve cache coherence by tracking and propagating changes to shared data.
keyPoints: Define the concept in your own words
Give a small example
Mention a common pitfall or best practice

open_questions.title: Compile time and run time.
open_questions.description: Explain compile time and run time.?
open_questions.prompt: You are evaluating a junior-level candidate. Answer the question: "Explain compile time and run time.?" Requirements: - Define the concept in your own words - Give a small example - Mention a common pitfall or best practice Style: - Clear, structured, concise. - Use code snippets only if they add clarity. - Avoid vague statements.
open_questions.aiEvaluationHint: Expect the answer to address: Define the concept in your own words; Give a small example; Mention a common pitfall or best practice. Penalize answers that miss key requirements.

referenceAnswers.text: Compile Time refers to the phase in which source code written in a programming language is converted by a compiler into machine code. During compile time, the compiler performs tasks like syntax analysis, semantic analysis, and code optimization. Errors such as syntax errors and type mismatches are detected at this stage. Run Time, on the other hand, is the phase when the compiled program is executed by a computer. It involves actual operation executions, memory management, and error handling that occurs while the application runs. Runtime errors can include exceptions like division by zero or accessing invalid memory locations.
keyPoints: Define the concept in your own words
Give a small example
Mention a common pitfall or best practice

open_questions.title: MESI
open_questions.description: What is MESI?
open_questions.prompt: You are evaluating a junior-level candidate. Answer the question: "What is MESI?" Requirements: - Define the concept in your own words - Give a small example - Mention a common pitfall or best practice Style: - Clear, structured, concise. - Use code snippets only if they add clarity. - Avoid vague statements.
open_questions.aiEvaluationHint: Expect the answer to address: Define the concept in your own words; Give a small example; Mention a common pitfall or best practice. Penalize answers that miss key requirements.

referenceAnswers.text: MESI is a cache coherence protocol used in multiprocessor systems. It stands for "Modified, Exclusive, Shared, Invalid," which are the four states a cache line can be in. The protocol ensures that multiple caches storing copies of the same data remain consistent, and it optimizes performance by reducing the need to write data back to main memory. Each state indicates the status of the data in the cache line and controls the read/write operations to that data: Modified: The cache line is only in the current cache and has been changed from the value in main memory (dirty). This cache is responsible for updating the main memory. Exclusive: The cache line is only in the current cache and matches main memory (clean). Shared: The cache line may be stored in other caches of the system and matches main memory. Invalid: The cache line is invalid or empty.
keyPoints: Define the concept in your own words
Give a small example
Mention a common pitfall or best practice

open_questions.title: Volatile memory and provide some examples
open_questions.description: What is volatile memory and provide some examples?
open_questions.prompt: You are evaluating a mid-level candidate. Answer the question: "What is volatile memory and provide some examples?" Requirements: - Define the concept in your own words - Give a small example - Mention a common pitfall or best practice Style: - Clear, structured, concise. - Use code snippets only if they add clarity. - Avoid vague statements.
open_questions.aiEvaluationHint: Expect the answer to address: Define the concept in your own words; Give a small example; Mention a common pitfall or best practice. Penalize answers that miss key requirements.

referenceAnswers.text: Volatile memory is a type of computer memory that requires power to maintain the stored information. When the power is turned off, the data stored in volatile memory is lost. This type of memory is primarily used for temporary data storage while the device is powered on. Examples of volatile memory include: Random Access Memory (RAM): Used in computers and smartphones to store data that the CPU needs quick access to while operating. Cache Memory: Found within CPUs or allocated on RAM, used to speed up access to frequently used data.
keyPoints: Define the concept in your own words
Give a small example
Mention a common pitfall or best practice

open_questions.title: Non-volatile memory and provide some examples
open_questions.description: What is non-volatile memory and provide some examples?
open_questions.prompt: You are evaluating a mid-level candidate. Answer the question: "What is non-volatile memory and provide some examples?" Requirements: - Define the concept in your own words - Give a small example - Mention a common pitfall or best practice Style: - Clear, structured, concise. - Use code snippets only if they add clarity. - Avoid vague statements.
open_questions.aiEvaluationHint: Expect the answer to address: Define the concept in your own words; Give a small example; Mention a common pitfall or best practice. Penalize answers that miss key requirements.

referenceAnswers.text: Non-volatile memory is a type of computer memory that retains data even when the device is powered off. It is used for long-term storage of data in electronic devices. Examples of non-volatile memory include: Solid State Drives (SSD): Used in computers and servers for fast data access and storage. Hard Disk Drives (HDD): Magnetic storage used for bulk data storage in personal computers and servers. Flash Memory: Common in USB flash drives, memory cards, and as storage in smartphones and tablets. ROM (Read-Only Memory): Stores firmware and system software that are rarely changed.
keyPoints: Define the concept in your own words
Give a small example
Mention a common pitfall or best practice

open_questions.title: A virtual machine
open_questions.description: What is a virtual machine?
open_questions.prompt: You are evaluating a junior-level candidate. Answer the question: "What is a virtual machine?" Requirements: - Define the concept in your own words - Give a small example - Mention a common pitfall or best practice Style: - Clear, structured, concise. - Use code snippets only if they add clarity. - Avoid vague statements.
open_questions.aiEvaluationHint: Expect the answer to address: Define the concept in your own words; Give a small example; Mention a common pitfall or best practice. Penalize answers that miss key requirements.

referenceAnswers.text: A virtual machine (VM) is a software-based emulation of a physical computer, running an operating system and applications just like a physical computer. It operates within a host system, using virtualized hardware resources managed by a hypervisor, which enables multiple VMs to share the same physical hardware securely and efficiently.
keyPoints: Define the concept in your own words
Give a small example
Mention a common pitfall or best practice

open_questions.title: The concept of pipelining in computer
open_questions.description: Explain the concept of pipelining in computer architecture.?
open_questions.prompt: You are evaluating a junior-level candidate. Answer the question: "Explain the concept of pipelining in computer architecture.?" Requirements: - Define the concept in your own words - Give a small example - Mention a common pitfall or best practice Style: - Clear, structured, concise. - Use code snippets only if they add clarity. - Avoid vague statements.
open_questions.aiEvaluationHint: Expect the answer to address: Define the concept in your own words; Give a small example; Mention a common pitfall or best practice. Penalize answers that miss key requirements.

referenceAnswers.text: Pipelining in computer architecture is a technique where multiple instruction phases are overlapped in execution. It's analogous to an assembly line in a factory: just as each stage in an assembly line works on a different car at the same time, each stage in a pipeline processes a different instruction or data stream simultaneously. This leads to more efficient use of the processor, as it reduces the time to complete an instruction and increases the overall throughput of the system. The main stages in a typical instruction pipeline include fetching the instruction, decoding it, executing it, and writing back the results.
keyPoints: Define the concept in your own words
Give a small example
Mention a common pitfall or best practice

open_questions.title: The different types of interrupts in
open_questions.description: What are the different types of interrupts in a microprocessor system?
open_questions.prompt: You are evaluating a junior-level candidate. Answer the question: "What are the different types of interrupts in a microprocessor system?" Requirements: - Define the concept in your own words - Give a small example - Mention a common pitfall or best practice Style: - Clear, structured, concise. - Use code snippets only if they add clarity. - Avoid vague statements.
open_questions.aiEvaluationHint: Expect the answer to address: Define the concept in your own words; Give a small example; Mention a common pitfall or best practice. Penalize answers that miss key requirements.

referenceAnswers.text: Maskable Interrupts: These can be enabled or disabled by the processor. They are used for routine tasks and can be ignored or delayed. Non-Maskable Interrupts (NMI): These cannot be disabled. They are used for urgent tasks, like hardware failures. External Interrupts: Originated from external sources, such as I/O devices. They signal events like input ready or output complete. Internal Interrupts: Generated within the processor, like arithmetic overflow, division by zero, or illegal instruction. Software Interrupts: Triggered by executing a specific instruction, typically used for system calls in an operating system.
keyPoints: Define the concept in your own words
Give a small example
Mention a common pitfall or best practice

open_questions.title: The different hazards
open_questions.description: What are the different hazards?
open_questions.prompt: You are evaluating a junior-level candidate. Answer the question: "What are the different hazards?" Requirements: - Define the concept in your own words - Give a small example - Mention a common pitfall or best practice Style: - Clear, structured, concise. - Use code snippets only if they add clarity. - Avoid vague statements.
open_questions.aiEvaluationHint: Expect the answer to address: Define the concept in your own words; Give a small example; Mention a common pitfall or best practice. Penalize answers that miss key requirements.

referenceAnswers.text: In computer architecture, hazards refer to conditions that can occur within the pipeline of a processor that prevent the next instruction in the instruction stream from executing during its designated clock cycle. There are three primary types of hazards: Structural Hazards: Arise from resource conflicts when the hardware cannot support all possible combinations of instructions simultaneously. Data Hazards: Occur when instructions that are pipelined are waiting for data to be computed or retrieved. They are subdivided into: Read After Write (RAW): A dependency where a subsequent instruction requires data from a previous instruction. Write After Read (WAR): Occurs when an instruction requires a resource that a previous instruction is using to produce a result. Write After Write (WAW): Happens when two instructions that write to the same location are queued concurrently. Control Hazards: Occur due to the pipelining of branches and other instructions that alter the program counter. They are typically handled by mechanisms like branch prediction.
keyPoints: Define the concept in your own words
Give a small example
Mention a common pitfall or best practice

open_questions.title: A snooping protocol
open_questions.description: What is a snooping protocol?
open_questions.prompt: You are evaluating a junior-level candidate. Answer the question: "What is a snooping protocol?" Requirements: - Define the concept in your own words - Give a small example - Mention a common pitfall or best practice Style: - Clear, structured, concise. - Use code snippets only if they add clarity. - Avoid vague statements.
open_questions.aiEvaluationHint: Expect the answer to address: Define the concept in your own words; Give a small example; Mention a common pitfall or best practice. Penalize answers that miss key requirements.

referenceAnswers.text: A snooping protocol is a method used in multiprocessor computer architectures to maintain cache coherency, ensuring that all caches in the system reflect the same view of memory. In a snooping protocol, each cache controller monitors (or "snoops") the data traffic on a shared bus to determine if other caches have copies of a block of memory that it wants to read or write. When a processor writes data, the snooping mechanism checks if that data is stored in another processor's cache and updates or invalidates the corresponding entries, maintaining data consistency across all caches. This protocol is commonly used in bus-based shared memory systems.
keyPoints: Define the concept in your own words
Give a small example
Mention a common pitfall or best practice

open_questions.title: The easiest way to determine cache
open_questions.description: What is the easiest way to determine cache locations in which to store memory blocks?
open_questions.prompt: You are evaluating a mid-level candidate. Answer the question: "What is the easiest way to determine cache locations in which to store memory blocks?" Requirements: - Define the concept in your own words - Give a small example - Mention a common pitfall or best practice Style: - Clear, structured, concise. - Use code snippets only if they add clarity. - Avoid vague statements.
open_questions.aiEvaluationHint: Expect the answer to address: Define the concept in your own words; Give a small example; Mention a common pitfall or best practice. Penalize answers that miss key requirements.

referenceAnswers.text: The easiest way to determine cache locations for storing memory blocks is through a technique called "Direct Mapping." In direct mapping, each block of main memory maps to exactly one cache line. The specific cache line is determined using a simple formula: (Block address modulo number of cache blocks). This straightforward method ensures a unique and consistent cache location for each memory block, making the determination process efficient and easy to implement.
keyPoints: Define the concept in your own words
Give a small example
Mention a common pitfall or best practice

open_questions.title: Mention what are the different types

open_questions.prompt: You are evaluating a junior-level candidate. Answer the question: "Mention what are the different types of fields that are part of an instruction?" Requirements: - Define the concept in your own words - Give a small example - Mention a common pitfall or best practice Style: - Clear, structured, concise. - Use code snippets only if they add clarity. - Avoid vague statements.
open_questions.aiEvaluationHint: Expect the answer to address: Define the concept in your own words; Give a small example; Mention a common pitfall or best practice. Penalize answers that miss key requirements.

referenceAnswers.text: An instruction in computer architecture typically consists of several fields, each serving a specific purpose in the instruction's execution: Opcode (Operation Code): Specifies the operation to be performed (like add, subtract, load, store). Source Operands: Identify the registers or memory locations where the input data for the operation can be found. Destination Operand: Indicates where the result of the operation should be stored. Immediate Value: A constant value or a literal that is part of the instruction itself. Addressing Mode: Specifies how to calculate the effective address of the operand if it is in memory.
keyPoints: Define the concept in your own words
Give a small example
Mention a common pitfall or best practice

open_questions.title: The difference between RISC and CISC
open_questions.description: Explain the difference between RISC and CISC architectures.?
open_questions.prompt: You are evaluating a junior-level candidate. Answer the question: "Explain the difference between RISC and CISC architectures.?" Requirements: - Define the concept in your own words - Give a small example - Mention a common pitfall or best practice Style: - Clear, structured, concise. - Use code snippets only if they add clarity. - Avoid vague statements.
open_questions.aiEvaluationHint: Expect the answer to address: Define the concept in your own words; Give a small example; Mention a common pitfall or best practice. Penalize answers that miss key requirements.

referenceAnswers.text: RISC (Reduced Instruction Set Computer) architectures use a smaller set of simple and fixed-length instructions, optimizing for simplicity and execution speed. CISC (Complex Instruction Set Computer) architectures, on the other hand, have a larger set of complex and variable-length instructions, aiming to reduce the number of instructions needed to perform a task. RISC architectures typically have a simpler and more streamlined pipeline design, while CISC architectures can perform more complex operations in a single instruction.
keyPoints: Define the concept in your own words
Give a small example
Mention a common pitfall or best practice

open_questions.title: Branch prediction in computer architecture.
open_questions.description: What is branch prediction in computer architecture.?
open_questions.prompt: You are evaluating a junior-level candidate. Answer the question: "What is branch prediction in computer architecture.?" Requirements: - Define the concept in your own words - Give a small example - Mention a common pitfall or best practice Style: - Clear, structured, concise. - Use code snippets only if they add clarity. - Avoid vague statements.
open_questions.aiEvaluationHint: Expect the answer to address: Define the concept in your own words; Give a small example; Mention a common pitfall or best practice. Penalize answers that miss key requirements.

referenceAnswers.text: Branch prediction is a technique used in computer processors to guess the outcome of a conditional branch instruction before it is executed. Its purpose is to improve the flow in the instruction pipeline. The processor predicts whether the branch will be taken or not taken and continues execution according to this prediction. If the prediction is correct, this results in improved performance; if incorrect, the pre-fetched and pre-executed instructions are discarded, and the pipeline is corrected, which can cause a delay.
keyPoints: Define the concept in your own words
Give a small example
Mention a common pitfall or best practice

open_questions.title: The concept of out-of-order execution in
open_questions.description: Explain the concept of out-of-order execution in modern CPUs.?
open_questions.prompt: You are evaluating a junior-level candidate. Answer the question: "Explain the concept of out-of-order execution in modern CPUs.?" open_questions.aiEvaluationHint: Expect the answer to address: Define the concept in your own words; Give a small example; Mention a common pitfall or best practice. Penalize answers that miss key requirements.

referenceAnswers.text: Out-of-order execution is a CPU design technique that allows instructions to be executed in a different order than they were originally fetched. It improves instruction-level parallelism by enabling the CPU to execute independent instructions simultaneously, even if they are not in sequential order. This technique can help utilize the CPU's execution units more efficiently.
keyPoints: Define the concept in your own words
Give a small example
Mention a common pitfall or best practice

open_questions.title: The purpose of the memory management
open_questions.description: What is the purpose of the memory management unit (MMU) in computer architecture.?
open_questions.prompt: You are evaluating a mid-level candidate. Answer the question: "What is the purpose of the memory management unit (MMU) in computer architecture.?" open_questions.aiEvaluationHint: Expect the answer to address: Define the concept in your own words; Give a small example; Mention a common pitfall or best practice. Penalize answers that miss key requirements.

referenceAnswers.text: The MMU is responsible for translating virtual addresses used by programs into physical addresses in memory. It enables virtual memory, which provides the illusion of a larger address space than physically available RAM. The MMU helps manage memory allocation, protection, and isolation between processes.

Give a small example
Mention a common pitfall or best practice

open_questions.title: Speculative execution in CPU architecture.
open_questions.description: What is speculative execution in CPU architecture.?
open_questions.prompt: You are evaluating a junior-level candidate. Answer the question: "What is speculative execution in CPU architecture.?" Requirements: - Define the concept in your own words - Give a small example - Mention a common pitfall or best practice Style: - Clear, structured, concise. - Use code snippets only if they add clarity. - Avoid vague statements.
open_questions.aiEvaluationHint: Expect the answer to address: Define the concept in your own words; Give a small example; Mention a common pitfall or best practice. Penalize answers that miss key requirements.

referenceAnswers.text: Speculative execution is a technique used by modern CPUs to execute instructions before it is certain they will be needed. It helps improve performance by keeping the CPU busy and reducing the impact of instruction dependencies and stalls. However, speculative execution can also introduce security vulnerabilities, as seen in the Spectre and Meltdown exploits.
keyPoints: Define the concept in your own words
Give a small example
Mention a common pitfall or best practice

open_questions.title: The concept of a branch target
open_questions.description: Explain the concept of a branch target buffer (BTB) in the context of instruction fetching.?
open_questions.prompt: You are evaluating a junior-level candidate. Answer the question: "Explain the concept of a branch target buffer (BTB) in the context of instruction fetching.?" Requirements: - Define the concept in your own words - Give a small example - Mention a common pitfall or best practice Style: - Clear, structured, concise. - Use code snippets only if they add clarity. - Avoid vague statements.
open_questions.aiEvaluationHint: Expect the answer to address: Define the concept in your own words; Give a small example; Mention a common pitfall or best practice. Penalize answers that miss key requirements.

referenceAnswers.text: A branch target buffer (BTB) is a cache-like structure that stores the target addresses of recently executed branch instructions. It helps improve CPU performance by predicting the target address of branches, reducing the delay caused by branch instruction execution. When the BTB prediction is correct, the CPU can fetch and execute instructions efficiently.
keyPoints: Define the concept in your own words
Give a small example
Mention a common pitfall or best practice

referenceAnswers.text: A memory hierarchy consists of multiple levels of memory with varying speeds and sizes. The primary purpose is to provide a trade-off between speed and storage capacity. Fast, but small, caches are placed closer to the CPU to reduce access times, while slower, but larger, main memory and secondary storage provide additional storage capacity.
keyPoints: Define the concept in your own words
Give a small example
Mention a common pitfall or best practice

open_questions.title: The concept of instruction-level parallelism (ILP)
open_questions.description: Explain the concept of instruction-level parallelism (ILP) in CPUs.?
open_questions.prompt: You are evaluating a junior-level candidate. Answer the question: "Explain the concept of instruction-level parallelism (ILP) in CPUs.?" Requirements: - Define the concept in your own words - Give a small example - Mention a common pitfall or best practice Style: - Clear, structured, concise. - Use code snippets only if they add clarity. - Avoid vague statements.
open_questions.aiEvaluationHint: Expect the answer to address: Define the concept in your own words; Give a small example; Mention a common pitfall or best practice. Penalize answers that miss key requirements.

referenceAnswers.text: Instruction-level parallelism (ILP) is the ability of a CPU to execute multiple instructions simultaneously. There are two main types of ILP: data-level parallelism (DLP) and control-level parallelism (CLP). DLP involves executing multiple data operations in parallel, while CLP involves executing multiple control instructions in parallel. Achieving ILP faces challenges like instruction dependencies, branch prediction, and hardware constraints.
keyPoints: Define the concept in your own words
Give a small example
Mention a common pitfall or best practice

referenceAnswers.text: The memory controller is responsible for managing data transfer between the CPU and RAM. It controls memory access, coordinates read and write operations, and handles memory requests from the CPU. The memory controller also manages the timing and performance of memory operations.
keyPoints: Define the concept in your own words
Give a small example
Mention a common pitfall or best practice

referenceAnswers.text: Vector processing involves performing the same operation on multiple data elements simultaneously. It differs from scalar processing, which operates on individual data elements one at a time. Vector processing is advantageous for tasks that involve repetitive mathematical operations on large datasets, as it can significantly improve processing speed through parallelism.

open_questions.title: The role of the microarchitecture in

referenceAnswers.text: The microarchitecture, also known as the CPU's internal architecture, defines how the CPU is implemented at the hardware level. It includes details about pipelines, caches, registers, and other internal components. The instruction set architecture (ISA) defines the CPU's external interface, specifying the instructions and their behavior that software can use to interact with the CPU.
keyPoints: Define the concept in your own words

Mention a common pitfall or best practice

open_questions.title: The purpose of the memory hierarchy's
open_questions.description: What is the purpose of the memory hierarchy's write-back and write-through policies?
open_questions.prompt: You are evaluating a mid-level candidate. Answer the question: "What is the purpose of the memory hierarchy's write-back and write-through policies?" Requirements: - Define the concept in your own words - Give a small example - Mention a common pitfall or best practice Style: - Clear, structured, concise. - Use code snippets only if they add clarity. - Avoid vague statements.
open_questions.aiEvaluationHint: Expect the answer to address: Define the concept in your own words; Give a small example; Mention a common pitfall or best practice. Penalize answers that miss key requirements.

referenceAnswers.text: Write-back and write-through are cache management policies. Write-back caches write data to the cache first and later update main memory, improving performance but potentially causing data inconsistency in case of crashes. Write-through caches write data to both the cache and main memory simultaneously, ensuring data consistency but potentially impacting performance.
keyPoints: Define the concept in your own words
Give a small example
Mention a common pitfall or best practice

open_questions.title: The concept of memory latency
open_questions.description: What is the concept of memory latency?
open_questions.prompt: You are evaluating a mid-level candidate. Answer the question: "What is the concept of memory latency?" Requirements: - Define the concept in your own words - Give a small example - Mention a common pitfall or best practice Style: - Clear, structured, concise. - Use code snippets only if they add clarity. - Avoid vague statements.
open_questions.aiEvaluationHint: Expect the answer to address: Define the concept in your own words; Give a small example; Mention a common pitfall or best practice. Penalize answers that miss key requirements.

referenceAnswers.text: Memory latency refers to the delay or time it takes for the CPU to access data from memory. High memory latency can lead to performance bottlenecks, as the CPU spends more time waiting for data to be fetched. Techniques like caching and out-of-order execution are used to mitigate the impact of memory latency.
keyPoints: Define the concept in your own words
Give a small example
Mention a common pitfall or best practice

open_questions.title: A virtual memory on a computer
open_questions.description: What is a virtual memory on a computer?
open_questions.prompt: You are evaluating a mid-level candidate. Answer the question: "What is a virtual memory on a computer?" Requirements: - Define the concept in your own words - Give a small example - Mention a common pitfall or best practice Style: - Clear, structured, concise. - Use code snippets only if they add clarity. - Avoid vague statements.
open_questions.aiEvaluationHint: Expect the answer to address: Define the concept in your own words; Give a small example; Mention a common pitfall or best practice. Penalize answers that miss key requirements.

referenceAnswers.text: Virtual memory is a memory management capability of an operating system (OS) that uses hardware and software to allow a computer to compensate for physical memory shortages, by temporarily transferring data from random access memory (RAM) to disk storage. This process creates an illusion to users of a very large (main) memory. It enables a computer to run larger applications or multiple applications simultaneously without relying solely on physical memory in the system. Virtual memory combines the computer's RAM with temporary space on the hard disk. When RAM runs low, virtual memory moves data to a space called a paging file or swap space, allowing the system's RAM to focus on running applications, thus enhancing the overall efficiency and performance.
keyPoints: Define the concept in your own words
Give a small example
Mention a common pitfall or best practice

open_questions.title: The two hardware methods to establish
open_questions.description: What are the two hardware methods to establish a priority?
open_questions.prompt: You are evaluating a junior-level candidate. Answer the question: "What are the two hardware methods to establish a priority?" Requirements: - Define the concept in your own words - Give a small example - Mention a common pitfall or best practice Style: - Clear, structured, concise. - Use code snippets only if they add clarity. - Avoid vague statements.
open_questions.aiEvaluationHint: Expect the answer to address: Define the concept in your own words; Give a small example; Mention a common pitfall or best practice. Penalize answers that miss key requirements.

referenceAnswers.text: Daisy Chaining: This method assigns priority based on the physical position of devices on a daisy chain. The closer a device is to the CPU in the chain, the higher its priority. Parallel Priority Interrupt: In this method, each device is connected to a common bus through its own interrupt line. Priority is established by the hardware, often using a priority encoder, which selects the highest-priority request among all the interrupting devices.
keyPoints: Define the concept in your own words
Give a small example
Mention a common pitfall or best practice

open_questions.title: The role of a TLB (Translation
open_questions.description: Explain the role of a TLB (Translation Lookaside Buffer) in virtual memory systems.?
open_questions.prompt: You are evaluating a mid-level candidate. Answer the question: "Explain the role of a TLB (Translation Lookaside Buffer) in virtual memory systems.?" Requirements: - Define the concept in your own words - Give a small example - Mention a common pitfall or best practice Style: - Clear, structured, concise. - Use code snippets only if they add clarity. - Avoid vague statements.
open_questions.aiEvaluationHint: Expect the answer to address: Define the concept in your own words; Give a small example; Mention a common pitfall or best practice. Penalize answers that miss key requirements.

referenceAnswers.text: A TLB is a hardware cache that stores recently used virtual-to-physical address mappings. It speeds up address translation by allowing the CPU to access frequently used translations directly from the TLB, reducing the need to access the page table in main memory. TLBs are crucial for efficient virtual memory management.
keyPoints: Define the concept in your own words
Give a small example
Mention a common pitfall or best practice

referenceAnswers.text: SIMD processing allows a single instruction to operate on multiple data elements simultaneously. It is commonly used in applications that require parallel processing of data, such as multimedia processing, scientific simulations, and graphics rendering, where the same operation is performed on multiple data elements.

open_questions.title: The difference between synchronous and asynchronous
open_questions.description: What is the difference between synchronous and asynchronous processor architectures?
open_questions.prompt: You are evaluating a junior-level candidate. Answer the question: "What is the difference between synchronous and asynchronous processor architectures?" Requirements: - Define the concept in your own words - Give a small example - Mention a common pitfall or best practice Style: - Clear, structured, concise. - Use code snippets only if they add clarity. - Avoid vague statements.
open_questions.aiEvaluationHint: Expect the answer to address: Define the concept in your own words; Give a small example; Mention a common pitfall or best practice. Penalize answers that miss key requirements.

referenceAnswers.text: Synchronous processor architectures follow a clock signal, executing instructions at specific clock cycles. Asynchronous architectures do not rely on a fixed clock signal and execute instructions when their dependencies are met. Synchronous architectures are more common but may have performance limitations, while asynchronous architectures offer potential power and performance benefits.
keyPoints: Define the concept in your own words
Give a small example
Mention a common pitfall or best practice

open_questions.title: DMA

open_questions.prompt: You are evaluating a junior-level candidate. Answer the question: "What is DMA?" open_questions.aiEvaluationHint: Expect the answer to address: Define the concept in your own words; Give a small example; Mention a common pitfall or best practice. Penalize answers that miss key requirements.

referenceAnswers.text: Direct Memory Access (DMA) is a feature in computer systems that allows certain hardware subsystems to access main system memory (RAM) independently of the central processing unit (CPU). This capability enables peripherals like disk drive controllers and network cards to transfer data to or from the memory without burdening the CPU with these operations.
keyPoints: Define the concept in your own words
Give a small example
Mention a common pitfall or best practice

open_questions.title: What is horizontal micro code
open_questions.description: Explain what is horizontal micro code?
open_questions.prompt: You are evaluating a junior-level candidate. Answer the question: "Explain what is horizontal micro code?" Requirements: - Define the concept in your own words - Give a small example - Mention a common pitfall or best practice Style: - Clear, structured, concise. - Use code snippets only if they add clarity. - Avoid vague statements.
open_questions.aiEvaluationHint: Expect the answer to address: Define the concept in your own words; Give a small example; Mention a common pitfall or best practice. Penalize answers that miss key requirements.

referenceAnswers.text: Horizontal microcode is a type of microcode used in computer processors, where each microinstruction contains control bits that directly correspond to various control signals of the processor. In horizontal microcoding, microinstructions are wide, with many bits, each controlling specific parts of the CPU's hardware in parallel. This allows for detailed and complex control of the CPU's functionality on a cycle-by-cycle basis, enabling efficient and finely tuned processor operations. However, the complexity and size of horizontal microcode can make it more challenging to write and maintain compared to vertical microcode.
keyPoints: Define the concept in your own words
Give a small example
Mention a common pitfall or best practice

open_questions.title: What is vertical micro code
open_questions.description: Explain what is vertical micro code?
open_questions.prompt: You are evaluating a junior-level candidate. Answer the question: "Explain what is vertical micro code?" Requirements: - Define the concept in your own words - Give a small example - Mention a common pitfall or best practice Style: - Clear, structured, concise. - Use code snippets only if they add clarity. - Avoid vague statements.
open_questions.aiEvaluationHint: Expect the answer to address: Define the concept in your own words; Give a small example; Mention a common pitfall or best practice. Penalize answers that miss key requirements.

referenceAnswers.text: Vertical microcode is a type of microcode used in computer processors, where each microinstruction is relatively compact and typically represents higher-level operations. In vertical microcoding, a microinstruction contains a smaller number of bits, each of which acts as a field that specifies more complex operations or sequences of operations. This approach requires decoding the microinstruction into more detailed control signals for the processor's hardware. Vertical microcode is generally more space-efficient than horizontal microcode, but it can be less efficient in terms of execution speed due to the additional decoding step.
keyPoints: Define the concept in your own words
Give a small example
Mention a common pitfall or best practice

open_questions.title: The types of micro-operations
open_questions.description: What are the types of micro-operations?
open_questions.prompt: You are evaluating a junior-level candidate. Answer the question: "What are the types of micro-operations?" Requirements: - Define the concept in your own words - Give a small example - Mention a common pitfall or best practice Style: - Clear, structured, concise. - Use code snippets only if they add clarity. - Avoid vague statements.
open_questions.aiEvaluationHint: Expect the answer to address: Define the concept in your own words; Give a small example; Mention a common pitfall or best practice. Penalize answers that miss key requirements.

referenceAnswers.text: Register Transfer Micro-operations: Involve transferring data between registers. Arithmetic Micro-operations: Perform arithmetic operations on numeric data stored in registers, such as addition, subtraction, increment, and decrement. Logic Micro-operations: Execute bitwise logical operations like AND, OR, XOR, and NOT on bit patterns in the registers. Shift Micro-operations: Move the bits within a register to the left or right, used in tasks like alignment and multiplication/division by powers of two. Input/Output Micro-operations: Facilitate data transfer between I/O devices and the central processing unit or memory.
keyPoints: Define the concept in your own words
Give a small example
Mention a common pitfall or best practice

open_questions.title: The difference between little-endian and big-endian
open_questions.description: What is the difference between little-endian and big-endian byte ordering in computer memory storage?
open_questions.prompt: You are evaluating a mid-level candidate. Answer the question: "What is the difference between little-endian and big-endian byte ordering in computer memory storage?" Requirements: - Define the concept in your own words - Give a small example - Mention a common pitfall or best practice Style: - Clear, structured, concise. - Use code snippets only if they add clarity. - Avoid vague statements.
open_questions.aiEvaluationHint: Expect the answer to address: Define the concept in your own words; Give a small example; Mention a common pitfall or best practice. Penalize answers that miss key requirements.

referenceAnswers.text: Little-endian byte ordering stores the least significant byte of a data word at the lowest memory address, while big-endian byte ordering stores the most significant byte at the lowest memory address. The choice of byte ordering affects how data is stored and retrieved in multi-byte data types and can impact data interchange between systems with different byte orders.
keyPoints: Define the concept in your own words
Give a small example
Mention a common pitfall or best practice

open_questions.title: The concept of superscalar architecture in
open_questions.description: Explain the concept of superscalar architecture in CPUs.?
open_questions.prompt: You are evaluating a junior-level candidate. Answer the question: "Explain the concept of superscalar architecture in CPUs.?" open_questions.aiEvaluationHint: Expect the answer to address: Define the concept in your own words; Give a small example; Mention a common pitfall or best practice. Penalize answers that miss key requirements.

referenceAnswers.text: Superscalar architecture allows a CPU to issue and execute multiple instructions simultaneously in a single clock cycle, taking advantage of instruction-level parallelism. Scalar architecture processes one instruction at a time, while VLIW (Very Long Instruction Word) architecture schedules multiple instructions in advance but without dynamic reordering like superscalar processors.

Mention a common pitfall or best practice

open_questions.title: The role of an instruction cache
open_questions.description: What is the role of an instruction cache (I-cache) and a data cache (D-cache) in a CPU?
open_questions.prompt: You are evaluating a junior-level candidate. Answer the question: "What is the role of an instruction cache (I-cache) and a data cache (D-cache) in a CPU?" Requirements: - Define the concept in your own words - Give a small example - Mention a common pitfall or best practice Style: - Clear, structured, concise. - Use code snippets only if they add clarity. - Avoid vague statements.
open_questions.aiEvaluationHint: Expect the answer to address: Define the concept in your own words; Give a small example; Mention a common pitfall or best practice. Penalize answers that miss key requirements.

referenceAnswers.text: The instruction cache (I-cache) stores instructions fetched from memory, while the data cache (D-cache) stores data accessed by the program. Both caches reduce memory access latency by providing faster access to frequently used data and instructions. Caches operate on the principle of locality, where recently accessed items are likely to be accessed again.
keyPoints: Define the concept in your own words
Give a small example
Mention a common pitfall or best practice

open_questions.title: Can you name some of the
open_questions.description: Can you name some of the common rules of assembly language?
open_questions.prompt: You are evaluating a junior-level candidate. Answer the question: "Can you name some of the common rules of assembly language?" Requirements: - Define the concept in your own words - Give a small example - Mention a common pitfall or best practice Style: - Clear, structured, concise. - Use code snippets only if they add clarity. - Avoid vague statements.
open_questions.aiEvaluationHint: Expect the answer to address: Define the concept in your own words; Give a small example; Mention a common pitfall or best practice. Penalize answers that miss key requirements.

referenceAnswers.text: Common rules of assembly language, which vary slightly depending on the specific assembly language and processor architecture, typically include: Syntax: Every instruction generally consists of an opcode (operation code) and zero or more operands. Labels: Used to mark positions within code, commonly for jump instructions and data declarations. Comments: Marked by specific characters (like ; or #), they are used for adding explanations or annotations, and are ignored by the assembler. Directives: Special instructions that direct the assembler to perform specific tasks during the assembly process, like defining constants or reserving space. Data Definitions: Instructions for defining variable data and initializing memory spaces. Instruction Constraints: Certain instructions only work with specific registers or memory types. Addressing Modes: Different ways to specify operands, like immediate, register, or indirect addressing.
keyPoints: Define the concept in your own words
Give a small example
Mention a common pitfall or best practice

open_questions.title: The five stages in a DLX
open_questions.description: What are the five stages in a DLX pipeline?
open_questions.prompt: You are evaluating a junior-level candidate. Answer the question: "What are the five stages in a DLX pipeline?" Requirements: - Define the concept in your own words - Give a small example - Mention a common pitfall or best practice Style: - Clear, structured, concise. - Use code snippets only if they add clarity. - Avoid vague statements.
open_questions.aiEvaluationHint: Expect the answer to address: Define the concept in your own words; Give a small example; Mention a common pitfall or best practice. Penalize answers that miss key requirements.

referenceAnswers.text: The five stages in a DLX pipeline, a classic RISC (Reduced Instruction Set Computer) pipeline, are: IF (Instruction Fetch): Retrieves the next instruction from memory. ID (Instruction Decode and Register Fetch): Decodes the fetched instruction and reads the necessary registers. EX (Execution or Address Calculation): Executes the instruction or calculates the address for memory operations. MEM (Memory Access): Reads from or writes to memory (for load/store instructions). WB (Write Back): Writes the results back to the register file.
keyPoints: Define the concept in your own words
Give a small example
Mention a common pitfall or best practice

open_questions.title: Flip-flops
open_questions.description: What are flip-flops?
open_questions.prompt: You are evaluating a junior-level candidate. Answer the question: "What are flip-flops?" Requirements: - Define the concept in your own words - Give a small example - Mention a common pitfall or best practice Style: - Clear, structured, concise. - Use code snippets only if they add clarity. - Avoid vague statements.
open_questions.aiEvaluationHint: Expect the answer to address: Define the concept in your own words; Give a small example; Mention a common pitfall or best practice. Penalize answers that miss key requirements.

referenceAnswers.text: Flip-flops are basic digital memory circuitry units used in electronics and computer systems. They are bistable devices, meaning they have two stable states, which can store a binary value of either 0 or 1. Flip-flops are capable of maintaining a binary state until it is changed by an input signal, making them foundational elements in building memory and data storage devices. They are used to store state information and form the basic building blocks for registers, counters, and other complex memory-related components in digital systems.
keyPoints: Define the concept in your own words
Give a small example
Mention a common pitfall or best practice

open_questions.title: Latches
open_questions.description: What are latches?
open_questions.prompt: You are evaluating a junior-level candidate. Answer the question: "What are latches?" Requirements: - Define the concept in your own words - Give a small example - Mention a common pitfall or best practice Style: - Clear, structured, concise. - Use code snippets only if they add clarity. - Avoid vague statements.
open_questions.aiEvaluationHint: Expect the answer to address: Define the concept in your own words; Give a small example; Mention a common pitfall or best practice. Penalize answers that miss key requirements.

referenceAnswers.text: Latches are basic electronic devices used in digital circuits, functioning as a form of temporary storage. They are capable of holding one bit of information and maintaining that state until it is changed by an external signal. Latches operate on the principle of feedback, where the output is looped back to the input to maintain the state. They are used in various applications for storing data, creating delay circuits, and stabilizing volatile signals. There are different types of latches, such as the D-latch and the SR-latch, each with its specific operational characteristics and uses.
keyPoints: Define the concept in your own words
Give a small example
Mention a common pitfall or best practice

open_questions.title: The difference between latches and flip-flops
open_questions.description: What is the difference between latches and flip-flops?
open_questions.prompt: You are evaluating a junior-level candidate. Answer the question: "What is the difference between latches and flip-flops?" Requirements: - Define the concept in your own words - Give a small example - Mention a common pitfall or best practice Style: - Clear, structured, concise. - Use code snippets only if they add clarity. - Avoid vague statements.
open_questions.aiEvaluationHint: Expect the answer to address: Define the concept in your own words; Give a small example; Mention a common pitfall or best practice. Penalize answers that miss key requirements.

referenceAnswers.text: The main difference between latches and flip-flops lies in their operating mechanisms and how they handle data: Latches: These are level-triggered devices, meaning they are sensitive to the input signals as long as they are active (high or low). A latch can change its output state as long as the control signal (like a clock) is in a particular state. Flip-Flops: These are edge-triggered devices, meaning they change their state only at specific moments, typically on the rising or falling edge of a control signal (like a clock pulse). Flip-flops are more suitable for synchronous circuits where changes occur in alignment with a clock signal.
keyPoints: Define the concept in your own words
Give a small example
Mention a common pitfall or best practice
